newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK handover must not be linked to China's MFN - Chan.
newsitem.headline: HK handover must not be linked to China's MFN - Chan.

text.p: Hong Kong urged the United States on Friday to renew China's special trading privileges and said the territory's handover to the mainland on July 1 should not be linked to the issue.
"Attaching Hong Kong-related conditions will only bring uncertainty, which in turn will undermine confidence in Hong Kong," Chief Secretary Anson Chan told a business assembly.

Britain hands Hong Kong back to China at midnight on June 30 after more than 150 years of colonial rule. Analysts expect the transition to be a major focal point when the U.S. Congress debates the renewal of China's Most Favoured Nation (MFN) trading status.
Chan said withdrawal of MFN would cut Hong Kong's gross domestic product (GDP) growth by 2.0 to 2.8 percentage points, and would lead to a loss of 61,000 to 86,000 jobs.
"We can ill afford such an economic blow in this critical year of our transition," Chan, Hong Kong's top civil servant, said.
Hong Kong's annual GDP growth was 4.7 percent in each of the past two years, and is forecast at 5.5 percent for 1997.
"And as MFN is a trade matter, our consistent position is that it should not be used as a tool to deal with non-trade issues," Chan said.
"So whilst we appreciate the interest in Hong Kong's future, we do not think it is a good idea to link Hong Kong's transition to the renewal exercise."
Hong Kong serves as an entrepot for China, and many Hong Kong manufacturers have moved their production bases to China to take advantage of lower production costs there.
U.S. President Bill Clinton has until June to decide on MFN, and Congress must then ratify that decision.
